Direct dehydrogenation of methanol to co-produce hydrogen and formaldehyde represents a promising chemical technology for generating clean fuel and critical chemical intermediates. However, the harsh reaction conditions pose significant challenges in developing efficient and durable catalysts for this process. In this research, Cr-modified CeMo/SiO2 supported catalyst (Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2) that achieves exceptional performance in methanol-to-anhydrous-formaldehyde conversion is reported. Strategic Cr doping with optimal metal loading and Ce/Mo ratio introduces customized oxygen vacancies, which is beneficial for catalytic kinetics. In addition, the interplay between Cr and Mo species not only weakens surface acidity but concurrently reinforces the Brønsted acid characteristics of Mo6 + centers. This dual functionality facilitates rapid desorption of carbon-containing intermediates during catalytic cycles, thereby mitigating surface coking and suppressing the reductive deactivation of high-valence Mo species. The achieved acid activity control/high-speed desorption/anti-coke synergy establishes a self-sustaining beneficial cycle that perpetuates catalytic efficiency. This synergistic mechanism fundamentally underpins the exceptional catalytic performance and long-term durability of the material. The optimized catalyst delivers 89.6 % methanol conversion with 92.9 % formaldehyde selectivity at 300 ℃. Remarkably, it retains 85.7 % conversion and 89.0 % selectivity over 240 h of continuous operation. This study effectively optimized the directional activity and durability of the supported catalyst through ingenious modification strategy, providing valuable insights for direct dehydrogenation of methanol and other similar catalytic processes. In recent years, the total global demand for formaldehyde has gradually increased, with the Asia-Pacific market taking the leading position, which makes the continuous optimization of formaldehyde production methods an extremely valuable task, although this has been carried out worldwide for decades [4,5]. Among the available production routes, the methanol dehydrogenation method has gained significant prominence in modern chemical synthesis due to its unique advantages. First, methanol serves as an environmentally benign feedstock that can be derived from renewable biomass resources, offering a sustainable alternative to traditional fossil fuel-based precursors [6,7]. In addition, the catalytic dehydrogenation process not only produces formaldehyde but also generates molecular hydrogen (H2) as the valuable byproduct [8,9]. H2, recognized as a clean energy carrier, plays a crucial role in addressing global climate change mitigation and facilitating energy transition strategies [10,11]. These attributes collectively position methanol dehydrogenation as a pivotal technology for sustainable chemical synthesis, aligning closely with the current industrial emphasis on eco-friendly processes and energy-efficient manufacturing paradigms. Unfortunately, direct dehydrogenation of methanol is not an "idealized" process that encounters significant technical challenges during implementation. A principal obstacle lies in water formation through parasitic oxidation pathways: hydrogen byproduct is susceptible to oxidation to generate water, while concurrent oxidative decomposition of methanol produces aqueous byproducts alongside various carbon-containing compounds [12]. These side reactions substantially compromise material utilization efficiency and product yield [13]. On the other side, due to the low boiling point of formaldehyde, it is prone to form azeotrope with water, making it difficult to purify by conventional rectification methods, thereby escalating separation difficulty and cost [14,15]. Moreover, the competitive generation of by-products such as carbon monoxide, dimethyl ether and acetic acid derivatives provides additional complexity [8,13,16]. The process of methanol dehydrogenation catalyzed by silver-based materials is a typical case. In the early phase of formaldehyde industry, the “silver method” was a relatively efficient process [17]. However, these catalysts require extreme operating temperatures exceeding 650 ℃ within the environment rich in methanol and water, posing inherent safety hazards while incurring substantial energy expenditures [18,19]. Modern iron-molybdenum-based catalysts demonstrate enhanced thermal stability and suppressed carbonaceous byproduct formation compared to silver materials, emerging as preferred alternatives in industrial applications [20]. Nevertheless, residual water persists in the final product, and the process demands ultrapure methanol feedstock [15,21]. The primary contributing factor to the excessive generation of water is attributed to the suboptimal catalytic performance in methanol conversion and the insufficient selectivity toward formaldehyde. Therefore, the development of direct dehydrogenation catalysts for methanol that achieve concurrent high conversion efficiency and high formaldehyde selectivity under mild thermal condition remains a critical challenge for the efficient production of high-quality formaldehyde and hydrogen. The recently reported catalysts for the dehydrogenation of methanol to anhydrous formaldehyde can mainly be classified into three categories: metal and metal oxide catalysts [4], alkali metal and their insoluble salt catalysts [22] and zeolite-based catalysts [23]. Among them, metal and metal oxide catalysts as typical supported catalysts, not only have an early origin time, but also have many advantages such as simple preparation process, diverse preparation methods and controllable loading. Conventionally, these catalysts are engineered by immobilizing catalytically active metallic or metal oxide species onto supports with appropriate surface acidity. Early investigations predominantly focused on IB and IIB metals as active components, exemplified by silver-based catalysts. Yamamoto et al. [24] demonstrated that phosphorus incorporation into Cu/SiO2 catalysts facilitated the formation of surface copper phosphate species, which effectively stabilized the oxidation state of Cu while reducing specific surface area. This modification strategy significantly enhanced formaldehyde selectivity, illustrating the critical role of trace elemental dopants in modulating catalytic performance and stability. However, monometallic catalysts inherently suffer from insufficient surface active oxygen species, resulting in limited methanol adsorption capacity and suboptimal intrinsic activity. Notably, Koivikko’s group [25] achieved enhanced methanol dehydrogenation kinetics by employing a SiO2-TiO2 composite support for V2O5 dispersion, where synergistic interactions between dual oxide carriers promoted the generation of abundant VOx species. A promising alternative involves the strategic design of bimetallic active components, which can directly tune catalytic functionalities through synergistic metal interactions. Despite emerging reports on dual-metal configurations, current systems predominantly adopt spinel-structured, leaving fundamental aspects of intermetallic cooperation and respective roles in the catalytic process inadequately explored [26,27]. Recent advances suggest that integrating dual-metal active sites with ternary elemental modification may enable breakthrough innovations, simultaneously addressing long-standing challenges in catalytic activity, product selectivity, and long-term stability through multifunctional engineering of surface chemistry and electronic structure. Although with few reports, but integrating dual-metal active sites with third elemental modification may enable breakthrough innovations, simultaneously addressing long-standing challenges in catalytic activity, product selectivity, and long-term stability through multifunctional engineering of surface chemistry and electronic structure. Herein, we report the chromium-modified supported bimetallic catalyst which with cerium and molybdenum oxides serve as dual active components. The optimized catalyst exhibits exceptional low-temperature catalytic activity and stability in methanol dehydrogenation for anhydrous formaldehyde production. The analysis results elucidate that synergistic interactions between the dual active components establish fundamental catalytic properties, with Mo6+ species functioning as Brønsted acid sites to facilitate the desorption energy barrier reduction of critical intermediates. Crucially, chromium incorporation induces oxygen vacancy generation while simultaneously suppressing carbon deposition and maintaining Mo6+ valence state stability, thereby achieving concurrent enhancement in both catalytic performance and durability. This study highlights a promising strategy for advancing supported bimetallic catalysts through targeted doping modifications, providing novel insights into the design principles of advanced catalytic materials for selective dehydrogenation reactions. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and catalysts synthesis A typical synthesis procedure of Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2 catalyst is described as follows: Initially, 1 g of ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, 99.9 %) was dissolved in 20 ml deionized water under vigorous magnetic stirring for 1 h in a three-neck flask. Subsequently, 12.8 g of 40 wt% high-concentration silica sol was added dropwise to the precursor solution, followed by an additional 1 h of homogenization (denoted as Solution A). Separately, Solution B was prepared by dissolving 0.282 g cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6 H2O, 99.9 %) and 0.258 g chromium(III) nitrate nonahydrate (Cr(NO3)3·9 H2O, 99.9 %) in 15 ml deionized water under vigorous stirring for 1 h. Solution B was introduced into Solution A via a controlled dropwise addition under continuous agitation, yielding a homogeneous yellow colloidal suspension. The resultant sol was aged at 75 ℃ for 18 h in a thermostated oil bath with mechanical stirring, followed by drying at 100 ℃ for 12 h in a blower drying oven. The dried precursor was ground into a fine powder and calcined in a muffle furnace under static air at 600 ℃ for 3 h (heating rate: 5 ℃ min−1), yielding the final catalyst designated as Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2. To prepare catalysts with different Cr loading, stoichiometric adjustments were made to the quantities of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, and Cr(NO3)3·9H2O while maintaining identical synthesis protocols (Crx-Ce1Mo6/SiO2). For Ce1Mo6/SiO2 synthesis, the procedure was identical except for omitting Cr(NO3)3·9H2O during solution B preparation. Similarly, CexMoy/SiO2 catalysts with different Ce/Mo ratios were fabricated by modulating the initial amounts of (NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O and Ce(NO3)3·6H2O while preserving other experimental parameters. 2.2 Catalytic testing methods The catalytic reaction of methanol dehydrogenation to anhydrous formaldehyde was carried out in a fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 13 mm in stainless steel tubes. The feeding part was composed of a rotameter, a bubbler, a low-temperature constant temperature bath and a heating tape. High-purity nitrogen gas was adjusted to 200 ml/min through a pressure reducing valve and a mass flowmeter and then introduced into the methanol bubbler. The methanol was carried into the reaction tube through the pipeline tightly wound with the heating tape by bubbling. To prevent methanol gas from condensing in the pipeline between the outlet of the evaporator and the inlet at the top of the reactor, the temperature of the heating tape was set at 100 ℃. The reaction section consisted of a thermoelectric furnace, a 13 mm stainless steel reaction tube and four thermocouples. Three thermocouples were placed in the thermoelectric furnace to measure the reaction temperature in the upper, middle and lower sections of the stainless steel reaction tube. The details of the physical characterization can be found in the Supplementary Material. 3 Results and discussion Catalysts with varying Ce/Mo ratios were synthesized via sol-gel method while maintaining a total active component loading of 18 wt%. As illustrated in Fig. 1a and Fig. 1b, the catalytic performance for methanol dehydrogenation to anhydrous formaldehyde exhibits a volcano-type relationship with Mo/Ce ratio, reaching maximum activity at the optimal stoichiometry of Ce:Mo = 1:6. As the material is prepared through high-temperature calcination, the main components on the surface of the catalyst are the oxides of cerium and molybdenum, where MoO3 provided Brønsted acid sites critical for reaction kinetics. The hexavalent Mo⁶⁺ species has been identified as the important active center for methanol dehydrogenation, as evidenced in prior studies [28]. Notably, monotonic performance degradation occurs at both Mo-rich and Ce-rich compositions, suggesting stringent dependence on balanced surface acidity modulated by MoO3 content. The acidity will be discussed in detail in the following text. Control experiments with single-component catalysts demonstrate markedly inferior activity compared to bimetallic counterparts, highlighting indispensable synergistic interactions between Ce and Mo species (Figure S1a and Figure S1b). Guided by the optimized Ce/Mo ratio, chromium was introduced as the third component to investigate its influence. Systematic evaluation of Cr content (the mass percentage of Cr in the total active components) reveals maximal catalytic enhancement at 5 wt% Cr loading (Fig. 1c and Fig. 1d). The 5 %Cr-Ce₁Mo₆/SiO₂ catalyst achieved 89.6 % methanol conversion with 92.9 % formaldehyde selectivity at 300 ℃. Moreover, the complete product composition generated by this catalytic system is comprehensively documented in Table S1. Table S2 summarizes the research results of recent related works. It is exciting that the performance of 5 %Cr-Ce₁Mo₆/SiO₂ is among the leading ones. Especially under the premise of low-temperature catalysis, the data presented in this work have significant advantages. Interestingly, no linear correlation emerges between Cr content and catalytic performance, suggesting a unique promotion mechanism rather than direct redox participation. In the subsequent discussion, the catalyst with 5 % Cr proportion was marked as Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2. Fig. 1e compares the overall catalytic capabilities of Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2 and Ce1Mo6/SiO2. The material modified by Cr has a more superior performance. Although Cr has no direct activity, its involvement affects the Ce and Mo components in a special way. Furthermore, under the same test and reaction condition, the continuous catalytic capabilities of the two materials were also compared. Overall, materials with Cr additives can achieve better continuous catalysis. Fig. 1f shows the exceptional durability of Cr-modified catalyst, retaining 85.7 % conversion and 89.0 % selectivity with marginal 4.4 % and 4.2 % declines after 240 h at 300 ℃, respectively. In stark contrast, the Cr-free counterpart exhibited rapid deactivation within 36 h. The main reason for the decrease in activity is the coke deposition of the catalyst surface. The corresponding data for Ce1Mo6/SiO2 lasted until 240 h are 34.9 % and 19.4 %. The phase composition and crystalline structure of the materials were investigated by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD). Fig. 2a displays the XRD patterns of Cr-Ce₁Mo₆/SiO₂ and Ce₁Mo₆/SiO₂ catalysts. The diffraction peaks observed in Ce₁Mo₆/SiO₂ predominantly correspond to CeO₂ (PDF#43–1002) species, MoO₃ (PDF#47–1320) species and SiO₂ (PDF#14–0654) species. The existence of these characteristic peaks can preliminarily confirm that the coexistence of cerium and molybdenum oxides as principal components. Upon Cr incorporation, the diffraction pattern exhibits enhanced complexity with emerging peaks assignable to Cr₂(MoO₄)₃ (PDF#20–0309) species and CrMoO₄ (PDF#29–0452) species, indicative of chemical interactions between Cr and Mo species leading to the formation of polymetallic composites rather than discrete monometallic oxides [29]. Moreover, Cr mainly interacts with the Mo element, which can also be confirmed by the undegraded characteristic peaks of CeO2 at 28.6° and 47.5°. Fig. 2b presents the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of two representative samples. Both Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2 and Ce1Mo6/SiO2 exhibit characteristic type-IV isotherms with H2-type hysteresis loops in the relative pressure range of 0.5–1.0 (P/Po), indicative of predominant mesoporous structures. This structural feature is further corroborated by the pore size distribution curves in Fig. 2c, which demonstrate narrow pore size distributions centered between 2 and 10 nm, revealing highly uniform mesoporous ordering within the support matrix. As summarized in Table S3, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area analysis reveals minimal alterations in specific surface area and pore structure following Cr incorporation, confirming the preservation of mesoporous dominance. The hierarchical mesoporous system provides distinct advantages for catalytic applications [30]: (i) The interconnected mesochannels enable rapid molecular transport of reactants (methanol) and products (formaldehyde, hydrogen), effectively mitigating mass transfer limitations; (ii) Reduced diffusion path lengths minimize kinetic restrictions during reaction cycles; (iii) The open pore architecture decreases residence time of reactive intermediates, thereby suppressing carbon deposition and parasitic side reactions while enhancing product selectivity. These synergistic effects collectively contribute to the superior catalytic selectivity and stability observed in these materials. The microstructure and surface characteristics of the synthesized Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2 were systematically investigated using transmission electron microscopy (TEM), as illustrated in Fig. 3. As shown in Fig. 3a, the material consists of a substrate and uniformly dispersed nanoparticles, which correspond to the supported metal oxide species. High-magnification imaging (Fig. 3b) enables a more detailed characterization of these particles, revealing that the diameters range from 2 to 5 nm. The nanoscale and well-dispersed nature of these catalytic components is beneficial for enhancing the catalytic activity. The nanoparticles and their surrounding regions display clear crystalline features, with distinct lattice fringes that can be indexed to specific crystallographic planes of CeO₂, MoO₃, and CrMoO₄, respectively. These observations are consistent with the XRD analysis. Elemental mapping images from Fig. 3c further confirms a homogeneous distribution of all constituent elements without detectable agglomeration, and the measured elemental composition aligns well with the expected results. Comparative TEM analyses of different samples reveal that variations in Ce/Mo component ratios and Cr incorporation induce negligible alterations in the overall morphology structures of catalysts (Figure S2). Table S4 shows the inductively coupled plasma (ICP) data of the material, which confirms the composition of the material again, and the proportion of Cr is relatively low, existing in the form of doping on the material surface, which is mainly used to modify the active components of Ce and Mo. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to analyze the valence state and electronic state of surface elements of the materials, and the key role of Cr element was further discussed. In the complete survey spectra of Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2 (Figure S3b), the characteristic peaks of key elements such as Ce, Mo, Cr, Si and O can be observed, while there is no characteristic peak of Cr element in the spectra for Ce1Mo6/SiO2 (Figure S3a). High-resolution Ce 3d spectra ( Fig. 4a) exhibits characteristic spin-orbit splitting into 3d₅/₂ and 3d₃/₂ components. Deconvolution of the Ce 3d₅/₂ region resolves four constituent peaks at 882.2 eV (Ce⁴⁺), 885.7 eV (Ce³⁺), 889.9 eV (Ce⁴⁺) and 899.9 eV (Ce⁴⁺), while the Ce 3d₃/₂ region showed peaks at 904.3 eV, 908.4 eV, and 916.6 eV corresponding to Ce⁴⁺, Ce³ ⁺ and Ce⁴⁺ species, respectively. The presence of thee peaks in the spectral characterization indicates that the catalyst surface exhibits a substantial population of Ce4+/Ce3+ redox couples. Notably, Cr incorporation into the Ce1Mo6/SiO2 composite induces a pronounced redistribution of Ce oxidation states, thereby resulting in emerging additional characteristic peaks of Ce4+ species This phenomenon demonstrates a significant enhancement in the relative abundance of Ce4+. Mo 3d spectra (Fig. 4b) demonstrated characteristic doublets at 232.1 eV and 235.3 eV, corresponding to Mo 3d₅/₂ and Mo 3d₃/₂ respectively and confirming the exclusive presence of Mo⁶⁺ species without detectable lower-valent molybdenum states (Mo4+ and Mo5+), indicating that the Mo element on the catalyst surface exists only in the form of a high-valent oxidation state. The deconvoluted O 1 s XPS spectrum of the Ce₁Mo₆/SiO₂ catalyst exhibits two distinct oxygen species: a shoulder peak at 529.9 eV corresponding to surface-chemisorbed oxygen species (Oads) and a dominant peak at 532.6 eV attributable to lattice oxygen (Olat) from metal oxide frameworks (Fig. 4c). The presence of substantial chemisorbed oxygen corroborates that the Ce⁴⁺/Ce³ ⁺ redox couple facilitates oxygen vacancy formation, thereby enhancing oxygen ion mobility within the catalyst structure[31,32]. Importantly, these surface oxygen species demonstrate significant catalytic functionality in accelerating the oxidative transformation of methanol to formaldehyde. Subsequent chromium incorporation induces a marked increase in the relative abundance of adsorbed oxygen species (Oads/Olat ratio), indicative of enhanced oxygen vacancy concentration. This enhancement originates from Cr-induced increase of Ce⁴+ species, which promotes oxygen vacancy generation. Crucially, Cr 2p₃/₂ analysis identifies three oxidation states via deconvolution: Cr²⁺, Cr³ ⁺ and Cr⁵⁺ (Fig. 4d). The dominance of Cr³ ⁺ species correlates with XRD-observed Cr₂(MoO₄)₃ phase formation, while the coexistence of multiple Cr oxidation states establishes robust Cr⁵⁺/Cr³ ⁺/Cr²⁺ redox couples. These multivalent Cr centers synergistically facilitate electron transfer processes, accounting for the observed Ce³ ⁺ oxidation enhancement and subsequent oxygen vacancy proliferation. This mechanistic understanding highlights the dual role of Cr as both modifier and electronic promoter in optimizing the redox properties of catalyst for methanol-to-formaldehyde conversion. The surface acid-base properties of catalysts critically influence reaction selectivity by modulating the stability and desorption kinetics of reaction intermediates. To elucidate the surface acidity characteristics, ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) analysis was performed as shown in Fig. 5a. Within the tested temperature range of 50–800 ℃, both samples exhibited two distinct temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) peaks. A characteristic desorption peak appeared in the low-temperature (LT) region (50–300 ℃) of the TPD profile, while another prominent peak emerged in the high-temperature (HT) region (300–800 ℃). The observed LT and HT peaks can be mechanistically ascribed to sequential desorption processes originating from weakly acidic sites and strongly acidic sites, respectively. Comparative analysis reveals that the Cr-modified catalyst demonstrated enhanced LT peak intensity with attenuated HT peak characteristics relative to the pristine material, indicative of increased weak acid site density and reduced strong acid sites. This modification resulted in an overall decrease in total surface acidity. The primary Brønsted acidity originates from Mo6+ centers, while Cr incorporation modulates the acidic properties through interactions with Mo6+ species. This moderate acidity optimization facilitates the desorption of carbonaceous intermediates and hydrogen species, thereby accelerating reaction kinetics [33,34]. On the other hand, Cr also adjusted the type of acid sites on the material surface. As evidenced by pyridine adsorption infrared spectroscopy (Py-IR) (Fig. 5b), the characteristic band at 1530–1560 cm⁻¹ , corresponding to pyridine adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites, exhibited enhanced intensity following Cr modification [35]. This observation confirms the increased Brønsted acidity, suggesting that Cr effectively enhances the intrinsic Brønsted acid characteristics of Mo⁶⁺ species, which further explains the rapid catalytic kinetics of material. Quantitative acid site analysis (Table S5) further revealed a substantial increase in the Brønsted-to-Lewis (B/L) acid ratio after Cr doping. Notably, while the total surface acid density of Cr-Ce₁Mo₆/SiO₂ decreased marginally, this phenomenon likely originates from partial conversion of strong acid sites to weaker ones during the structural reorganization induced by Cr incorporation. Temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) profiles were employed to investigate the reduction features of metal oxide species. All catalysts exhibit two distinct peaks (Fig. 5c), corresponding to the two-step reduction of Mo⁶⁺ as the primary active species. The low-temperature peak centered at approximately 500 ℃ represents the reduction of Mo⁶⁺ to Mo⁴⁺, while the high-temperature event near 700 ℃ corresponds to subsequent reduction to metallic Mo⁰[36]. Cr-Ce₁Mo₆/SiO₂ demonstrates a pronounced high-temperature shift in the first reduction step, indicating an elevated activation energy barrier for Mo⁶⁺ reduction. This fundamental alteration in redox thermodynamics reveals that Cr incorporation not only modifies surface catalytic properties but also stabilizes specific Mo-O-Cr coordinated structures, thereby enhancing the stability of Mo⁶⁺ species against premature deactivation during catalytic cycles. Combined with XRD results (Fig. 2a), the stable oxidation-state species can be attributed to the formation of new phases (Cr₂(MoO₄)₃ and CrMoO₄) induced by chromium incorporation. These Cr-Mo composite oxides not only deliver enhanced catalytic activity through synergistic interactions but also effectively stabilize the critical Mo-based active species, thereby maintaining beneficial chemical state under operational conditions. In addition to the relationship between the catalyst and the intermediate, the changes of the materials themselves at high temperatures were also discussed. thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted to investigate thermal stability evolution (Fig. 5d). First, all samples exhibit initial mass loss below 200 ℃, originating from the desorption of ambient moisture adsorbed during storage [36]. A gradual mass reduction observed between 200 and 700 ℃ corresponds to the liberation of physisorbed gases in pores and residual water molecules trapped within the mesoporous architecture of materials [37]. Notably, the pronounced mass loss above 700 ℃ reflects metal species volatilization, where Ce₁Mo₆/SiO₂ demonstrates more significant weight reduction compared to Cr-Ce₁Mo₆/SiO₂[29]. This differential behavior substantiates that chromium incorporation induces strong metal-support interaction (SMSI) that effectively stabilize active species against thermal degradation, thereby enhancing the material's thermostability. These findings align with the sustained catalytic performance at elevated temperatures observed in Fig. 1f. The exceptional operational stability exhibited by the optimized catalyst prompts further investigation into its deactivation mechanisms under prolonged operational conditions. The spent catalysts used in the deactivation mechanism analysis were the samples after continuous catalysis for 240 h. Figure S4 presents comparative XRD patterns of Ce1Mo6/SiO2 before and after stability testing. Post-reaction characterization reveals substantial attenuation of MoO3 characteristic diffraction peaks, which can be attributed to the volatilization and amorphous transformation of species. On the other side, the CeO2 diffraction peaks at 28.6° and 47.5° exhibit peak broadening indicating a decrease in the crystallinity of the species. Correspondingly, the XRD results of Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2 after the test shown in Fig. 6a present some characteristic peaks with obvious intensity decrease as well. Intriguingly, the diffraction peak at 22.6° corresponding to Cr2(MoO4)2 species exhibits enhanced intensity. These observations demonstrate that excess molybdenum oxide interacts with metallic components to form composite phases, which function as supplementary active species [38]. The Cr element plays a key role in promoting the formation of composite new phases. The coexistence of preserved original phases and newly formed crystalline structures indicates the protective effect of Cr in mitigating active species degradation, thereby contributing to enhanced catalyst longevity. Integrating the H2-TPR characterization data (Fig. 5c), the primary catalytic components can be identified as related species of Ce and Mo, while the Cr-Mo composite phase retains catalytically active high-valence Mo species. Crucially, chromium not only suppresses the reduction of Mo species but also facilitates their re-conversion into Cr-Mo heterostructure. Furthermore, Cr contributes to the structural stability by preserving the crystalline integrity of Ce-based phases. Post-reaction TEM characterization revealed varying degrees of morphological degradation in all catalyst samples compared to their pristine counterparts. While Cr-Ce₁Mo₆/SiO₂ exhibited distinct particle agglomeration, Ce₁Mo₆/SiO₂ completely lost its original nanoparticle architecture (Figure S5). This result indicates that the degree of damage caused by carbon deposition to the materials is inconsistent. To analyze the changes in the specific surface area and pore state of the catalyst during the reaction process, BET test was conducted for comparison. Figure S6a and Fig. 6b present the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms for Ce1Mo6/SiO2 and Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2 catalysts, respectively. Both spent catalysts maintain characteristic type IV isotherms, confirming the preservation of mesoporous architectures after prolonged stability testing for anhydrous formaldehyde production. However, the Ce1Mo6/SiO2 catalyst exhibits a substantial reduction in specific surface area and pore volume (Figure S6b and Table S3). The deterioration is attributed to carbonaceous byproduct accumulation within the porous network during side reactions of methanol dehydrogenation. In contrast, Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2 catalyst demonstrates superior structural stability under identical reaction conditions. The post-reaction sample showed only moderate surface area reduction while maintaining comparable pore volume parameters to its fresh counterpart (Figure S7). This pronounced enhancement in coke deposition resistance highlights the crucial role of chromium dopants in mitigating pore blockage and preserving the textural properties of the catalyst during extended catalytic operation. Since the weak acid sites on the surface of the catalyst are conducive to the reaction of methanol dehydrogenation to anhydrous formaldehyde, the changes in surface acidity before and after the reaction are discussed. After the long-term catalytic methanol dehydrogenation, both the LT peak and the HT peak for Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2 show the phenomenon of intensity decline, indicating the reduction in the number of weak and strong acid sites during the reaction process (Fig. 6c). Ce1Mo6/SiO2 demonstrates more pronounced surface acidity reduction (Figure S8). Given that Mo6+ species predominantly govern the acidic characteristics, Cr incorporation effectively stabilizes high-valence molybdenum species during extended catalytic operation, thereby mitigating carbonaceous deposition-induced site deactivation. This protective mechanism aligns with XRD observation. To further characterize the coke deposition of the catalysts, the Differential Thermal Analysis (DTA) curves were analyzed. As a function of temperature, the weight changes in each temperature interval are shown in Fig. 6d. These curves accurately describe the adhesion amount of carbon by-products on the material surface and the combustion temperature. Samples would exhibit broad combustion exotherms between 300 and 500 ℃, with peak intensities correlating directly with surface carbon accumulation [39]. Cr modification optimizes the weak acidic Mo6+ sites, enhancing intermediate desorption kinetics and substantially reducing coke retention through efficient detachment of carbon-containing intermediates. Concurrently, Cr-mediated material preserves surface acidity over prolonged durations, maintaining excellent desorption efficiency. This synergistic mutual circulation between acid site preservation and enhanced desorption dynamics establishes the fundamental basis for the catalyst's superior durability. The surface chemical evolution of Ce1Mo6/SiO2 and Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2 catalysts before and after stability testing was systematically investigated through XPS analysis to elucidate the coke deposition effects on elemental states. As shown in Figure S9, negligible variations in O 1 s spectra across all catalysts before and after testing indicate the absence of direct interactions between oxygen species and surface coke. Figure S10 and Fig. 7a are the Ce 3d spectra of Ce1Mo6/SiO2 and Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2 respectively. After a long period of operation, some characteristic peaks of Ce4+ have shifted and differentiated, but the overall Ce4+/Ce3+ ratio is approximately the same as the initial value. The maintenance of Ce4+ species ensures the existence of oxygen vacancies, enabling the material to undergo a long-term and rapid intermediate transformation process. Combined with the XRD conclusion, it can be known that during the catalytic process, Cr has a relatively low influence on the valence state of the Ce element, and its main role is to avoid the degradation of crystalline Ce species. Metal phases with high crystallinity usually have SMSI and more abundant active sites, which have a positive impact on thermal catalysis [40,41]. Post-reaction Mo 3d spectra analysis (Figure S11) identifies a deconvoluted Mo4+ peak at 230.4 eV for spent Ce1Mo6/SiO2, suggesting the partial reduction of Mo6+ species during operation [42]. This valence reduction correlates with surface acidity decline observed in NH3-TPD profiles, representing one critical factor for catalytic activity decay. In striking contrast, the Cr-modified counterpart maintains intact Mo6+ doublets in Fig. 7b, demonstrating the protective effect of Cr on molybdenum oxidation state stability and consequent preservation of surface acidity. Fig. 7c shows that the concentration of chromium ions in the higher valence state of Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2 has decreased after the stability test. When methanol molecules are adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst and react, since the activity of chromium is relatively lower than that of molybdenum-cerium, carbon deposits are more likely to form around high-valent Cr elements. The loss of trace Cr elements eventually led to a slight decrease in surface acidity and activity. All in all, the main changes of the material during the working process were analyzed through various characterizations, and its deactivation mechanism was determined. The Cr-modified catalyst exhibited exceptional long-term stability, with the enhancement mechanism attributed to two critical factors: (i) Chromium doping effectively moderates and stabilizes surface acidity while suppressing excessive reduction of high-valent molybdenum species, thereby mitigating carbonaceous deposition and preserving efficient desorption kinetics. (ii) The introduction of Cr significantly retards the amorphous transformation of cerium-molybdenum oxide phases, maintaining elevated catalytic activity at active sites through structural stabilization. This dual functionality ensures sustained catalytic performance by simultaneously addressing both surface poisoning mechanisms and bulk phase degradation processes. 4 Conclusion In summary, this paper designs a supported Cr-modified CeMo bimetallic catalyst with SiO2 as the carrier, which can efficiently and stably catalyze the dehydrogenation of methanol to anhydrous formaldehyde. The synergistic effect produced between the dual active components with optimal stoichiometric ratio has a positive impact on the thermal catalytic process. Owing to the further interaction between Cr and active species, additional oxygen vacancies and weak acid sites were generated on the surface of the modified material, optimizing the kinetic process and enabling the material to exhibit excellent catalytic activity and selectivity. This surface modification strategy effectively facilitates the activation of key reaction intermediates while suppressing undesired side pathways. In addition, the high-speed intermediate desorption process reduces the carbon deposits on the material surface, preserves the high-valent oxidation state of Mo weak acid sites, and ensures the durability of the catalyst. At 300 ℃, the Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2 catalyst demonstrated a methanol conversion rate of 89.6 % and a formaldehyde selectivity of 92.9 %. After 240 h of continuous catalytic process, the conversion rate and selectivity decreased by only 4.4 % and 4.2 % respectively. This study innovatively further modified the supported bimetallic catalyst. The resulting product has excellent performance and the preparation process is easy to scale up, with extremely high industrial potential. The concept of this work is expected to provide novel ideas for the dehydrogenation of methanol to anhydrous formaldehyde and other fields of thermal dehydrogenation. coredata.dc:description: Direct dehydrogenation of methanol to co-produce hydrogen and formaldehyde represents a promising chemical technology for generating clean fuel and critical chemical intermediates. However, the harsh reaction conditions pose significant challenges in developing efficient and durable catalysts for this process. In this research, Cr-modified CeMo/SiO2 supported catalyst (Cr-Ce1Mo6/SiO2) that achieves exceptional performance in methanol-to-anhydrous-formaldehyde conversion is reported. Strategic Cr doping with optimal metal loading and Ce/Mo ratio introduces customized oxygen vacancies, which is beneficial for catalytic kinetics. In addition, the interplay between Cr and Mo species not only weakens surface acidity but concurrently reinforces the Brønsted acid characteristics of Mo6 + centers. This dual functionality facilitates rapid desorption of carbon-containing intermediates during catalytic cycles, thereby mitigating surface coking and suppressing the reductive deactivation of high-valence Mo species. The achieved acid activity control/high-speed desorption/anti-coke synergy establishes a self-sustaining beneficial cycle that perpetuates catalytic efficiency. This synergistic mechanism fundamentally underpins the exceptional catalytic performance and long-term durability of the material. The optimized catalyst delivers 89.6 % methanol conversion with 92.9 % formaldehyde selectivity at 300 ℃. Remarkably, it retains 85.7 % conversion and 89.0 % selectivity over 240 h of continuous operation. This study effectively optimized the directional activity and durability of the supported catalyst through ingenious modification strategy, providing valuable insights for direct dehydrogenation of methanol and other similar catalytic processes.
